image.altText: PROXY: Qatar Qantas composite

items.synopsis: Two former heads of the national competition watchdog say the federal government's move to block Qatar Airways' request for extra flights to protect Qantas decreases competition and leaves travellers worse off.

title.children: 'I don't think anyone swallows that story': Flight Centre boss lashes government for putting Qantas before customers

image.altText: An Indigenous flag held by a hand in a yellow, red and black parka

items.synopsis: Six years ago, while the sun crept up into the crevices of Uluru, history was being made by a few hundred First Nations people. Now, the rest of Australia can join in, writes Bridget Brennan.

title.children: This is a major moment in our history — and we may never get a re-run

image.altText: Anthony Albanese standing in front of "VOTE YES" branding as he announces the date of the Voice to Parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Australians will cast their first referendum vote in more than two decades in October, deciding the fate of a constitutionally-enshrined Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice to Parliament.

title.children: October 14 set as Voice to Parliament referendum

image.altText: A middle-aged Aboriginal man raises his fist as two women standing beside him clap at a rally for the Yes campaign.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced a date for the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum. Look back on how it happened and the reaction in our blog.

title.children: The Voice referendum will happen on October 14, the PM has confirmed. How Australians reacted to the news

image.altText: A bespectacled man in a blue suit coat folds his arms as he stands before framed documents hung on a white wall.

items.synopsis: Police allege a Cantonese work of fiction Andrew Chan edited for a writing competition three years earlier violated Hong Kong's national security law, and when they found out he was overseas they threatened his family with arrest if they did not contact him.

title.children: A piece of fictional writing has this Brisbane-based activist fearing he can never return home to Hong Kong

image.altText: Dark storm clouds and lightning strikes in skies in south-east Queensland.

items.synopsis: A storm outbreak is set to hit broad parts of the east coast on Wednesday afternoon, with warnings of possible damaging winds and large hail for much of coastal New South Wales into south-east Queensland. Meanwhile, potentially record-breaking heat is building in the west.

title.children: East coast braces for severe storms as near-record-breaking heat builds in west

image.altText: Katta O'Donnell wears a black turtleneck and long hair, standing in a forest in a portrait.

items.synopsis: The federal government has agreed to settle a world-first court case accusing it of misleading investors by failing to disclose the risk climate change poses to its bonds.

title.children: In 2020, a uni student launched a world-first case against the federal government. They’ve now reached an agreement

image.altText: Judge Salvatore Vasta

items.synopsis: An Australian man has been awarded more than $300,000, after his lawyer successfully argued he was wrongly jailed by a judge who behaved like a character from Alice In Wonderland.

title.children: Man awarded $300k after suing 'Queen of Hearts' judge for wrongful imprisonment

image.altText: A close-up of a woman with pink lipstick and blonde hair

items.synopsis: Annastacia Palaszczuk asks for privacy after being tracked down and photographed by the media during her two-week holiday in Italy.

title.children: 'Everyone is entitled to leave': Queensland premier requests privacy after being snapped on overseas holiday

image.altText: woman reads book on couch

items.synopsis: A doctor says better understanding of menopause will lead to better outcomes for women, particularly in the workplace.

title.children: Women fed up with suffering in silence say menopause is everyone's issue. Here's why

image.altText: Man in suit stands in front of US flag

items.synopsis: In an operation dubbed "Duck Hunt", the FBI and partners seize control of malware network Qakbot, which has crippled millions of tech users for over 15 years.

title.children: 'Most devastating cybercriminal tools in history': Global investigation infiltrates malware network

image.altText: Movie poster for the latest installment in the Hunger Games, 'Catching Fire'

items.synopsis: A report tabled in SA parliament finds that the state's Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions suffers from a "dysfunctional and broken" workplace culture where staff "don't feel safe, valued, heard or seen".

title.children: SA prosecutors' office likened to Hunger Games in damning review of workplace culture

image.altText: A man looks on.

items.synopsis: When Luis Rubiales grabbed Jenni Hermoso's face and kissed her on the lips during post-match celebrations at Stadium Australia, Spaniards were forced to pick a side, and start a national conversation about chauvinism.

title.children: 'Something deeply rotten': Soccer, chauvinism and the national conversation Spain had to have

image.altText: A public toilet block in a park beneath a clear sky.

items.synopsis: Police are calling for public information as they investigate the "distressing" incident, which led to the boy being taken to hospital in Port Macquarie.

title.children: Boy, 8, injured by needle wrapped in toilet roll at popular NSW park

image.altText: Winter hail blanketed parts of Murwillumbah in northern NSW.

items.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology has cancelled a severe thunderstorm warning for parts of south-east Queensland, but still forecasts stormy weather.

title.children: South-east Queensland set for hail and stormy weather

image.altText: A person shopping at Australian grocery store, with a basket full of sparkling water, fruits and vegetables.

items.synopsis: Inflation cooled more than forecast over the 12 months to July, with the ABS monthly index showing consumer prices easing to an annual pace of 4.9 per cent last month.

title.children: Inflation eases more than forecast in July but housing costs continue to rise

image.altText: Darlington unit fire

items.synopsis: Police confirm that a body, believed to be a man aged in his 60s, has been located inside a Darlington unit following a fire on Wednesday morning.

title.children: Man's body found in burnt-out unit after blaze engulfed Sydney building

image.altText: A hand pointing a TV remote towards a TV, which displays the Netflix logo

items.synopsis: The streaming platform has always dominated the landscape, but for the first time since Netflix entered the Australian market — subscription numbers are down.

title.children: Is Netflix in its flop era? Subscribers are down for the first time since 2015

image.altText: An older person's hand holds a slip of paper, dropping it into a box.

items.synopsis: When does voting open for the Voice to Parliament referendum? What is voting in a referendum like? When will we know the result? Get to grips with how the first referendum in two decades will work.

title.children: Everything you need to know about voting in the Voice referendum

image.altText: The Australian, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags are carried by fans on the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

items.synopsis: With the date set for a vote on the Voice to Parliament, take a refresher on what proponents and opponents of the referendum proposal are arguing.

title.children: What do Yes and No supporters argue about the Voice to Parliament?

image.altText: Australian soldiers stand outside the funeral of Lt Col Harry Smith

items.synopsis: Lieutenant Colonel Harry Arthur Smith SG MC (Retd), renowned for guiding 100 Australian soldiers into battle against an enemy force of thousands in the Vietnam War, is being laid to rest today on the Sunshine Coast.

title.children: Legendary Long Tan military leader 'up there with the great figures of our war history' farewelled

image.altText: A fire burns behind palm trees with thick black smoke covering the sky

items.synopsis: Police say one child was caught after he returned to watch the blaze he allegedly lit destroy a Whitsunday house.

title.children: 12yo charged with arson after returning to watch a blaze that destroyed a vacant Whitsunday house

image.altText: Trees destroyed

items.synopsis: Trees covering the equivalent of 14 tennis courts of land have been cut and poisoned at Castle Cove, decimating important habitat for native animals.

title.children: 'Somebody could go to jail for it': $10k reward offered after 265 trees destroyed in Sydney waterfront reserve

image.altText: A woman with short dark hair stares at her reflection in a mirror, without smiling.

items.synopsis: Australia now has a 10-year road map on eating disorders. Here’s a look at what it includes.

title.children: The federal government has just released a national eating disorder strategy. Here's what that means

image.altText: A composite image of blurred out cards and a man in a bright shirt

items.synopsis: The Anti-Defamation Commission has taken aim at the Australian-made game, which markets itself as being "ideal for the Aussie sense of humour".

title.children: Human rights group calls for 'immoral and obscene' game which mocks holocaust, rape and incest to be canned

image.altText: The garden as it appeared in a 2020 listing

items.synopsis: Errol Stewart and his family company are facing charges over garden works at a heritage-listed Hobart property. Mr Stewart says the works were urgent, but the council says the works have damaged the heritage significance of the site.

title.children: 'It's my garden': Prominent developer defends changing heritage-listed garden without permit

image.altText: Ben Simmons sits and claps his hands

items.synopsis: Australia's first NBA All Star says he wants to join the Boomers as they try to defend or better their Olympic bronze medal from Tokyo, but he has made similar comments in the past.

title.children: 'My goal is to be on the Olympic team': Ben Simmons reveals Paris 2024 ambitions with Boomers

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Australian stocks closed higher on Wednesday, buoyed by inflation falling to 4.9 per cent, all but guaranteeing another pause in interest rates from the RBA next month. Look back on the day's business and finance news as it happened with our blog.

title.children: ASX closes higher as falling inflation sets the scene for a third-straight interest rate pause by the RBA — as it happened

image.altText: A woman in a green blazer speaks at a press conference.

items.synopsis: Jackie Jarvis tells parliament of her abortion after being raped in the early 1990s and why she didn't report it, as politicians debate reforms to termination laws in parliament.

title.children: 'A clear decision': WA minister reveals she was victim of date rape, had abortion

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair and glasses stares out the window while grasping a cup of tea.

items.synopsis: Analysis of Federal Court data has found 10 per cent of all forced bankruptcies across Australia are from strata levy debts.

title.children: Nicki owns a flat, but has gone into debt due to strata fees

image.altText: A picture of a smiling man's face, attached to a wooden cross outside.

items.synopsis: At the Krasnopilske military cemetery in eastern Ukraine, one of the first things you hear is weeping — the women here all know each other, but they're bound together for devastating reasons.

title.children: Ukraine doesn't release its number of war casualties — at this cemetery, the real toll is on show
